div.p: Mrs. Russell has returned home, telling me that she spoke to you about the possibility of my giving a talk or a reading in Chicago sometime about the first of March. I have been doing a great deal of that lately. I have already spoken in New York before the Poetry Society of America and the Cosmopolitan Club; and I have a talk there before the MacDowell Club on February 22nd, and another before the Colony Club on February 24th. I am usually paid fifty dollars for these occasions, and usually I am engaged by some club or some charity. I have been doing this, as you may very well guess, with a view to getting poetry more generally understood, Imagist poetry especially, although I have not confined myself to that; but I find that the preparation of these lectures takes so much time that I have been obliged to ask compensation.

Now supposing that there is no club or society in Chicago which would care to invite me to speak to them, it might be possible for me to hire a hall or a room in some club, taking the risk myself, and simply selling the tickets.

Here the International Institute for Girls in Spain gave a series of three “Poet’s Readings.” I was one of the poets. There were over two hundred people present, and they paid two dollars a ticket. Of course, I was only paid my usual fifty dollars, the rest of the money going to charity. But if I am obliged to take the risk of hiring the room, it seems to me I might make a good thing out of it, provided there are enough people in Chicago who would care to come to hear me. You know more about Chicago than I, and it may be that there is no one there to whom I should appeal, in which case I hope you will tell me so quite frankly.

Also it would be impossible for me here to arrange that sort of thing, to get the room, or to sell the tickets. I do not wish to put myself in the hands of a lecture bureau, like Lindsay, as I do not wish to do enough of this. But knowing you to be a public-spirited and influential person, and also one extremely interested in producing and fostering poetry, it occurs to me that you may not think me “cheeky” if I ask your advice in this matter. I should be very glad to hear from you as to what possibility there is for me to give a talk in your town, and how it could practically best be arranged.

I think the best time for me would be early in March, but of course that could be made to suit circumstances. After my New York lectures, I return here for a dinner which is being given for Masefield on the 26th of February, so I could not go out before that, as the early part of February is engaged. But I could make any March dates to suit yours, I think. Or I could put it off until April, if it seemed advisable. But I am anxious to go to Chicago as soon as possible, as I have various business matters to attend to there.

I trust, dear Mrs. Aldis, you will not think this an imposition. If the matter seems to you too much of a chore to concern yourself with, or if you do not think there would be any interesting such a talk, or if for any reason [sic] whatever you do not care for the idea, please tell me so quite frankly, and I shall perfectly understand. I have also written to Harriet Monroe on the subject, but I do not want either of you to take any trouble in the matter if you are busy.
